Corn_(maize)___Cercospora_leaf_spot Gray.overview: A fungal disease causing small, rectangular, gray-to-brown lesions on leaves, which can merge to cause significant damage.
treatment: Apply fungicides preventatively, especially during favorable conditions.
Consider using a fungicide with a multi-site mode of action.
prevention: Plant resistant or tolerant corn hybrids.
Implement crop rotation with non-host crops for at least two years.
Bury corn residue to reduce the fungal inoculum.

Corn_(maize)___Common_rust_.overview: A fungal disease characterized by small, cinnamon-brown pustules on leaves that release spores, which turn dark brown to black as the plant matures.
treatment: Fungicide application may be necessary for susceptible hybrids, especially during early stages of infection.
prevention: Plant rust-resistant corn hybrids.
Ensure proper plant nutrition to improve overall plant health and resistance.

Corn_(maize)___healthy.overview: A healthy corn plant with no signs of disease or pests.
treatment: No treatment required.
prevention: Continue with good agricultural practices, including proper irrigation, fertilization, and weed control.
Regularly scout the field for any signs of new diseases or pests.

Corn_(maize)___Northern_Leaf_Blight.overview: A fungal disease causing long, elliptical, grayish-green lesions on leaves, which can severely reduce photosynthesis.
treatment: Apply fungicides at the first sign of symptoms, focusing on protecting the ear leaf and above.
Consider multiple applications for prolonged protection.
prevention: Plant resistant hybrids.
Rotate crops to a non-host plant to break the disease cycle.
Till corn residue to reduce overwintering fungi.

Ginger_Bacterial_Wilt.overview: A soil-borne bacterial disease that causes rapid wilting and yellowing of leaves, leading to the collapse of the entire plant.
treatment: There is no effective chemical treatment once the plant is infected.
Remove and destroy all infected plants and rhizomes immediately.
Solarize the soil to kill the bacteria.
prevention: Use disease-free planting material from a reputable source.
Plant in well-drained soil and avoid over-irrigation.
Rotate crops and avoid planting in fields with a history of the disease.

Ginger_Healthy.overview: A healthy ginger plant with no signs of disease.
treatment: No treatment required.
prevention: Ensure proper drainage to prevent waterlogging and root rot.
Monitor plants regularly for any signs of disease and maintain good soil health.

Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.overview: A bacterial disease causing brown, scab-like spots on leaves and fruit, leading to defoliation and reduced yield.
treatment: Apply copper-based bactericides preventatively to control the spread.
Use sanitation practices to clean tools and equipment.
prevention: Use certified, disease-free seeds and transplants.
Prune plants to improve air circulation and reduce humidity.
Avoid overhead irrigation, which can splash bacteria from the soil to the leaves.

Pepper,_bell___healthy.overview: A healthy bell pepper plant with no signs of disease.
treatment: No treatment required.
prevention: Maintain a consistent watering schedule and provide adequate sunlight.
Regularly inspect plants for pests and diseases to ensure a healthy yield.

Potato___Early_blight.overview: A fungal disease causing small, dark-brown spots with concentric rings (target-like) on lower leaves.
treatment: Apply fungicides preventatively, especially during wet weather.
Ensure plants are well-nourished to resist stress.
prevention: Plant resistant potato varieties if available.
Remove infected leaves to slow the spread.
Use mulch to prevent soil from splashing onto leaves.

Potato___healthy.overview: A healthy potato plant with no signs of disease.
treatment: No treatment required.
prevention: Ensure proper spacing between plants for airflow.
Maintain consistent soil moisture and avoid waterlogging.
Check for signs of pests or nutrient deficiencies.

Potato___Late_blight.overview: A destructive fungal-like disease that causes water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems, leading to rapid decay.
treatment: Apply fungicides at the first sign of symptoms, and continue applications on a regular schedule.
Use a combination of different fungicides to prevent resistance.
prevention: Plant resistant varieties.
Remove and destroy all infected plant debris after harvest.
Avoid overhead irrigation and ensure good air circulation.

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.overview: A bacterial disease causing small, dark, water-soaked spots on leaves that can lead to leaf drop and scabbing on fruit.
treatment: Apply copper-based sprays preventatively, especially during warm, humid conditions.
Prune lower leaves to improve air circulation.
prevention: Use certified, disease-free seeds and transplants.
Avoid overhead watering to prevent splashing bacteria.

Tomato___Early_blight.overview: A common fungal disease that causes brown spots with concentric rings on lower leaves.
treatment: Remove and destroy infected leaves and plant debris.
Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or copper.
prevention: Ensure good plant spacing for air circulation.
Mulch to reduce soil splash that spreads the fungus.

Tomato___healthy.overview: A healthy tomato plant with no signs of disease.
treatment: No treatment required.
prevention: Provide adequate water and nutrients.
Support plants with stakes or cages to improve air circulation.
Monitor regularly for signs of pests or disease.

Tomato___Late_blight.overview: A highly destructive disease that causes large, irregular, dark-brown lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit, leading to rapid plant death.
treatment: Apply fungicides containing mancozeb or chlorothalonil at the first sign of disease.
Remove and destroy infected plants immediately to prevent spread.
prevention: Plant resistant varieties if available.
Avoid planting tomatoes near potatoes, as they can share the disease.
Prune lower branches to prevent soil splash.

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.overview: A fungal disease that first appears as light green or yellow spots on the upper leaf surface, with olive-green or brown velvety patches on the lower surface.
treatment: Apply fungicides if necessary, ensuring good coverage on the undersides of leaves.
Improve air circulation around plants by pruning.
prevention: Increase plant spacing to promote air flow.
Reduce humidity in greenhouses by using fans or vents.

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.overview: A fungal disease causing small, circular spots with dark brown margins and a tan center on leaves, often leading to defoliation.
treatment: Remove and destroy infected leaves.
Apply fungicides preventatively, especially during wet periods.
prevention: Mulch plants to prevent soil from splashing onto leaves.
Avoid overhead watering.

Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.overview: Tiny pests that feed on plant sap, causing stippling (tiny yellow or white spots) on the leaves, and can create fine webbing.
treatment: Spray plants with a strong stream of water to dislodge mites.
Use insecticidal soaps or neem oil as a control measure.
prevention: Introduce predatory mites as a biological control.
Keep plants well-watered to reduce stress, as mites thrive on stressed plants.

Tomato___Target_Spot.overview: A fungal disease that creates small, dark, circular spots on leaves, which may have a yellow halo and can develop into target-like lesions.
treatment: Remove infected leaves and plant debris from the ground.
Apply fungicides with active ingredients like azoxystrobin.
prevention: Ensure proper air circulation to keep foliage dry.
Avoid overhead irrigation, especially in the evening.

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.overview: A viral disease causing mottled, mosaic-like patterns on leaves, stunting of the plant, and deformed fruit.
treatment: There is no chemical cure for viral diseases.
Remove and destroy all infected plants to prevent the virus from spreading.
prevention: Wash hands and sterilize tools after handling infected plants.
Use virus-resistant varieties if available.

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.overview: A viral disease transmitted by whiteflies, causing leaves to curl upwards and become stunted, and flowers to drop, leading to no fruit production.
treatment: There is no cure for this virus.
Remove and destroy infected plants immediately to prevent the spread to other plants.
prevention: Control whitefly populations, which are the primary vector, using insecticides or reflective mulches.
Plant in areas where the virus is not prevalent.

Unknown.overview: The image is unclear or the plant is healthy. No specific disease has been detected.
treatment: No specific treatment recommended. If symptoms persist, a clearer image may be needed.
prevention: Continue monitoring the plant for any changes in health.

Yam_Anthracnose.overview: A fungal disease causing dark spots or lesions on leaves, stems, and tubers, which can lead to vine dieback and reduced yield.
treatment: Apply fungicides containing copper or mancozeb as a preventative measure during periods of high humidity.
Prune and destroy infected plant parts.
prevention: Use disease-free planting material from a trusted source.
Ensure proper field sanitation to remove crop residue.

Yam_Leaf_spot.overview: A fungal disease causing small, circular spots on yam leaves, which can merge and cause defoliation.
treatment: Apply fungicides to protect new growth.
Remove and destroy heavily infected leaves to reduce disease spread.
prevention: Rotate crops with non-yam species to break the disease cycle.
Maintain good air circulation through proper plant spacing.

Yam_Mosaic_Virus.overview: A viral disease causing mosaic patterns (light and dark green areas) on leaves, leaf distortion, and stunted plant growth.
treatment: There is no cure for viral diseases.
Remove and destroy infected plants promptly.
prevention: Use only certified, virus-free planting material.
Control insect vectors like aphids and mealybugs with insecticides.
